fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Time at which the certificate is first considered valid.

type: date

example: 2019-08-16T01:40:25Z

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Algorithm used to generate the public key.

type: keyword

example: RSA

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The curve used by the elliptic curve public key algorithm. This is algorithm specific.

type: keyword

example: nistp521

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Exponent used to derive the public key. This is algorithm specific.

type: long

example: 65537

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The size of the public key space in bits.

type: long

example: 2048

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Unique serial number issued by the certificate authority. For consistency, this must be encoded in base 16 and formatted without colons and uppercase characters.

type: keyword

example: 55FBB9C7DEBF09809D12CCAA

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Identifier for certificate signature algorithm. We recommend using names found in Go Lang Crypto library. See https://github.com/golang/go/blob/go1.14/src/crypto/x509/x509.go#L337-L353.

type: keyword

example: SHA256-RSA

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of common names (CN) of subject.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: shared.global.example.net

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of country (C) code

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: US

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Distinguished name (DN) of the certificate subject entity.

type: keyword

example: C=US, ST=California, L=San Francisco, O=Example, Inc., CN=shared.global.example.net

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of locality names (L)

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: San Francisco

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of organizations (O) of subject.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: Example, Inc.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of organizational units (OU) of subject.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of state or province names (ST, S, or P)

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: California

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing files.'>File</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Version of x509 format.

type: keyword

example: 3

fieldDescription:
Linux boot uuid taken from /proc/sys/kernel/random/boot_id. Note the boot_id value from /proc may or may not be the same in containers as on the host. Some container runtimes will bind mount a new boot_id value onto the proc file in each container.

type: keyword

example: 88a1f0ed-5ae5-41ee-af6b-41921c311872

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Percent CPU used which is normalized by the number of CPU cores and it ranges from 0 to 1.

Scaling factor: 1000.

For example: For a two core host, this value should be the average of the two cores, between 0 and 1.

type: scaled_float

system.cpu.utilization

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The total number of bytes (gauge) read successfully (aggregated from all disks) since the last metric collection.

type: long

system.disk.io

fieldDescription:
The total number of bytes (gauge) written successfully (aggregated from all disks) since the last metric collection.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.

type: keyword

example: CONTOSO

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Hostname of the host.

It normally contains what the hostname command returns on the host machine.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Unique host id.

As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.

Example: The current usage of beat.name.

type: keyword

host.id

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Host ip addresses.

type: ip

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

host.ip

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Host MAC addresses.

The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["00-00-5E-00-53-23", "00-00-5E-00-53-24"]

host.mac

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Name of the host.

It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

type: keyword

host.name

fieldDescription:
The number of bytes received (gauge) on all network interfaces by the host since the last metric collection.

type: long

system.network.io

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The number of packets (gauge) received on all network interfaces by the host since the last metric collection.

type: long

system.network.packet.count

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. The specific type designation for the entity as defined by its provider or system. This field provides more granular classification than the type field. Examples: aws_s3_bucket, gcp_cloud_storage_bucket, azure_blob_container would all map to entity type bucket. hardware , virtual , container , node , cloud_instance would all map to entity type host.

type: keyword

example: aws_s3_bucket

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. A standardized high-level classification of the entity. This provides a normalized way to group similar entities across different providers or systems. Example values: bucket, database, container, function, queue, host, user, application, session, cloud, orchestrator, etc. If an entity is nested under a top-level namespace like host or cloud, or similar, its type array should include the matching value for example, host or cloud.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

Important: The field value must be one of the following:

bucket, database, container, function, queue, host, user, application, service, session, cloud, orchestrator

To learn more about when to use which value, visit the page allowed values for entity.type

example: boston-dc

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Use the os.type field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.

If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

Expected values for this field:

* linux
* macos
* unix
* windows
* ios
* android

type: keyword

example: macos

os.type

Note: The expected values in ECS for os.type do not correspond with the values defined in semantic conventions!

fieldDescription:
Operating system architecture.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Linux boot uuid taken from /proc/sys/kernel/random/boot_id. Note the boot_id value from /proc may or may not be the same in containers as on the host. Some container runtimes will bind mount a new boot_id value onto the proc file in each container.

type: keyword

example: 88a1f0ed-5ae5-41ee-af6b-41921c311872

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Percent CPU used which is normalized by the number of CPU cores and it ranges from 0 to 1.

Scaling factor: 1000.

For example: For a two core host, this value should be the average of the two cores, between 0 and 1.

type: scaled_float

system.cpu.utilization

The total number of bytes (gauge) read successfully (aggregated from all disks) since the last metric collection.

system.disk.io

fieldDescription:
The total number of bytes (gauge) written successfully (aggregated from all disks) since the last metric collection.

system.disk.io

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.

For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

type: keyword

example: CONTOSO

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Hostname of the host.

It normally contains what the hostname command returns on the host machine.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Unique host id.

As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.

Example: The current usage of beat.name.

type: keyword

host.id

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Host ip addresses.

type: ip

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

host.ip

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Host MAC addresses.

The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["00-00-5E-00-53-23", "00-00-5E-00-53-24"]

host.mac

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the relevant computing instance.'>Host</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Name of the host.

It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

type: keyword

host.name

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Size in bytes of the request body.

type: long

example: 887

http.request.body.size

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The full HTTP request body.

type: wildcard

Multi-fields:

* http.request.body.content.text (type: match_only_text)

example: Hello world

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Total size in bytes of the request (body and headers).

type: long

example: 1437

http.request.size

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A unique identifier for each HTTP request to correlate logs between clients and servers in transactions.

The id may be contained in a non-standard HTTP header, such as X-Request-ID or X-Correlation-ID.

type: keyword

example: 123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
HTTP request method.

The value should retain its casing from the original event. For example, GET, get, and GeT are all considered valid values for this field.

type: keyword

example: POST

http.request.method_original

http.request.method

Note: http.request.method in SemConv is the known, normalized, upper case value of the request method, other than the ECS' http.request.method that retains casing from the original event.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Mime type of the body of the request.

This value must only be populated based on the content of the request body, not on the Content-Type header. Comparing the mime type of a request with the request's Content-Type header can be helpful in detecting threats or misconfigured clients.

type: keyword

example: image/gif

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Referrer for this HTTP request.

type: keyword

example: https://blog.example.com/

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Size in bytes of the response body.

type: long

example: 887

http.response.body.size

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The full HTTP response body.

type: wildcard

Multi-fields:

* http.response.body.content.text (type: match_only_text)

example: Hello world

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Total size in bytes of the response (body and headers).

type: long

example: 1437

http.response.size

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Mime type of the body of the response.

This value must only be populated based on the content of the response body, not on the Content-Type header. Comparing the mime type of a response with the response's Content-Type header can be helpful in detecting misconfigured servers.

type: keyword

example: image/gif

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
HTTP response status code.

type: long

example: 404

http.response.status_code

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an HTTP request.'>HTTP</abbr>
fieldDescription:
HTTP version.

type: keyword

example: 1.1

network.protocol.name

network.protocol.version

Note: In OTel SemConv, network.protocol.version specifies the HTTP version if the value of network.protocol.name is http.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields to describe observer interface information.'>Interface</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface alias as reported by the system, typically used in firewall implementations for e.g. inside, outside, or dmz logical interface naming.

example: outside

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields to describe observer interface information.'>Interface</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface ID as reported by an observer (typically SNMP interface ID).

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields to describe observer interface information.'>Interface</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface name as reported by the system.

type: keyword

example: eth0

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Full path to the log file this event came from, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

If the event wasn't read from a log file, do not populate this field.

type: keyword

example: /var/log/fun-times.log

log.file.path

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Original log level of the log event.

If the source of the event provides a log level or textual severity, this is the one that goes in log.level. If your source doesn't specify one, you may put your event transport's severity here (e.g. Syslog severity).

Some examples are warn, err, i, informational.

type: keyword

example: error

severity_text

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The name of the logger inside an application. This is usually the name of the class which initialized the logger, or can be a custom name.

type: keyword

example: org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.Bootstrap

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The line number of the file containing the source code which originated the log event.

type: long

example: 42

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The name of the file containing the source code which originated the log event.

Note that this field is not meant to capture the log file. The correct field to capture the log file is log.file.path.

type: keyword

example: Bootstrap.java

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The name of the function or method which originated the log event.

type: keyword

example: init

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The Syslog metadata of the event, if the event was transmitted via Syslog. Please see RFCs 5424 or 3164.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The device or application that originated the Syslog message, if available.

type: keyword

example: sshd

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The Syslog numeric facility of the log event, if available.

According to RFCs 5424 and 3164, this value should be an integer between 0 and 23.

type: long

example: 23

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The Syslog text-based facility of the log event, if available.

type: keyword

example: local7

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The hostname, FQDN, or IP of the machine that originally sent the Syslog message. This is sourced from the hostname field of the syslog header. Depending on the environment, this value may be different from the host that handled the event, especially if the host handling the events is acting as a collector.

type: keyword

example: example-host

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
An identifier for the type of Syslog message, if available. Only applicable for RFC 5424 messages.

type: keyword

example: ID47

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Syslog numeric priority of the event, if available.

According to RFCs 5424 and 3164, the priority is 8 * facility + severity. This number is therefore expected to contain a value between 0 and 191.

type: long

example: 135

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The process name or ID that originated the Syslog message, if available.

type: keyword

example: 12345

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The Syslog numeric severity of the log event, if available.

If the event source publishing via Syslog provides a different numeric severity value (e.g. firewall, IDS), your source's numeric severity should go to event.severity. If the event source does not specify a distinct severity, you can optionally copy the Syslog severity to event.severity.

type: long

example: 3

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The Syslog numeric severity of the log event, if available.

If the event source publishing via Syslog provides a different severity value (e.g. firewall, IDS), your source's text severity should go to log.level. If the event source does not specify a distinct severity, you can optionally copy the Syslog severity to log.level.

type: keyword

example: Error

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Structured data expressed in RFC 5424 messages, if available. These are key-value pairs formed from the structured data portion of the syslog message, as defined in RFC 5424 Section 6.3.

type: flattened

fieldSet: <abbr title='Details about the event's logging mechanism.'>Log</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The version of the Syslog protocol specification. Only applicable for RFC 5424 messages.

type: keyword

example: 1

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the Go language imports in a Mach-O file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.

The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

type: keyword

example: 10bddcb4cee42080f76c88d9ff964491

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of imported Go language element names and types.

type: flattened

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

type: boolean

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the imports in a Mach-O file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.

This is a synonym for symhash.

type: keyword

example: d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of imported element names and types.

type: flattened

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
An array containing an object for each section of the Mach-O file.

The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath macho.sections.*.

type: nested

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Mach-O Section List name.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Mach-O Section List physical size.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Mach-O Section List virtual size. This is always the same as physical_size.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Mac OS Mach Object file format (Mach-O) metadata.'>Mach-O Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the imports in a Mach-O file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.

This is a Mach-O implementation of the Windows PE imphash

type: keyword

example: d3ccf195b62a9279c3c19af1080497ec

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
When a specific application or service is identified from network connection details (source/dest IPs, ports, certificates, or wire format), this field captures the application's or service's name.

For example, the original event identifies the network connection being from a specific web service in a https network connection, like facebook or twitter.

The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

type: keyword

example: aim

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Total bytes transferred in both directions.

If source.bytes and destination.bytes are known, network.bytes is their sum.

type: long

example: 368

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of source and destination IPs and ports, as well as the protocol used in a communication. This is a tool-agnostic standard to identify flows.

Learn more at https://github.com/corelight/community-id-spec.

type: keyword

example: 1:hO+sN4H+MG5MY/8hIrXPqc4ZQz0=

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Direction of the network traffic.

When mapping events from a host-based monitoring context, populate this field from the host's point of view, using the values "ingress" or "egress".

When mapping events from a network or perimeter-based monitoring context, populate this field from the point of view of the network perimeter, using the values "inbound", "outbound", "internal" or "external".

Note that "internal" is not crossing perimeter boundaries, and is meant to describe communication between two hosts within the perimeter. Note also that "external" is meant to describe traffic between two hosts that are external to the perimeter. This could for example be useful for ISPs or VPN service providers.

Expected values for this field:

* ingress
* egress
* inbound
* outbound
* internal
* external
* unknown

type: keyword

example: inbound

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.

type: ip

example: 192.1.1.2

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
IANA Protocol Number (https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Standardized list of protocols. This aligns well with NetFlow and sFlow related logs which use the IANA Protocol Number.

type: keyword

example: 6

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Network.inner fields are added in addition to network.vlan fields to describe the innermost VLAN when q-in-q VLAN tagging is present. Allowed fields include vlan.id and vlan.name. Inner vlan fields are typically used when sending traffic with multiple 802.1q encapsulations to a network sensor (e.g. Zeek, Wireshark.)

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Name given by operators to sections of their network.

type: keyword

example: Guest Wifi

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Total packets transferred in both directions.

If source.packets and destination.packets are known, network.packets is their sum.

type: long

example: 24

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
In the OSI Model this would be the Application Layer protocol. For example, http, dns, or ssh.

The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

type: keyword

example: http

network.protocol.name

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)

The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

type: keyword

example: tcp

network.transport

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc

The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

type: keyword

example: ipv4

network.type

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

type: keyword

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

type: keyword

example: outside

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

type: keyword

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing the communication path over which the event happened.'>Network</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

type: keyword

example: outside

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Observer.egress holds information like interface number and name, vlan, and zone information to classify egress traffic. Single armed monitoring such as a network sensor on a span port should only use observer.ingress to categorize traffic.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Network zone of outbound traffic as reported by the observer to categorize the destination area of egress traffic, e.g. Internal, External, DMZ, HR, Legal, etc.

type: keyword

example: Public_Internet

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Hostname of the observer.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Observer.ingress holds information like interface number and name, vlan, and zone information to classify ingress traffic. Single armed monitoring such as a network sensor on a span port should only use observer.ingress to categorize traffic.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Network zone of incoming traffic as reported by the observer to categorize the source area of ingress traffic. e.g. internal, External, DMZ, HR, Legal, etc.

type: keyword

example: DMZ

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
IP addresses of the observer.

type: ip

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
MAC addresses of the observer.

The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["00-00-5E-00-53-23", "00-00-5E-00-53-24"]

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Custom name of the observer.

This is a name that can be given to an observer. This can be helpful for example if multiple firewalls of the same model are used in an organization.

If no custom name is needed, the field can be left empty.

type: keyword

example: 1_proxySG

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The product name of the observer.

type: keyword

example: s200

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Observer serial number.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The type of the observer the data is coming from.

There is no predefined list of observer types. Some examples are forwarder, firewall, ids, ips, proxy, poller, sensor, APM server.

type: keyword

example: firewall

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Vendor name of the observer.

type: keyword

example: Symantec

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Observer version.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface alias as reported by the system, typically used in firewall implementations for e.g. inside, outside, or dmz logical interface naming.

type: keyword

example: outside

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface ID as reported by an observer (typically SNMP interface ID).

type: keyword

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface name as reported by the system.

type: keyword

example: eth0

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

type: keyword

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

type: keyword

example: outside

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
City name.

type: keyword

example: Montreal

geo.locality.name

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Two-letter code representing continent's name.

type: keyword

example: NA

geo.continent.code

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Name of the continent.

type: keyword

example: North America

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Country ISO code.

type: keyword

example: CA

geo.country.iso_code

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Country name.

type: keyword

example: Canada

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Longitude and latitude.

type: geo_point

example: { "lon": -73.614830, "lat": 45.505918 }

geo.location.lat

geo.location.lon

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.

Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.

Not typically used in automated geolocation.

type: keyword

example: boston-dc

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Postal code associated with the location.

Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

type: keyword

example: 94040

geo.postal_code

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Region ISO code.

type: keyword

example: CA-QC

geo.region.iso_code

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Region name.

type: keyword

example: Quebec

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

type: keyword

example: America/Argentina/Buenos_Aires

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface alias as reported by the system, typically used in firewall implementations for e.g. inside, outside, or dmz logical interface naming.

type: keyword

example: outside

Interface ID as reported by an observer (typically SNMP interface ID).

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Interface name as reported by the system.

type: keyword

example: eth0

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

example: 10

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>

type: keyword

example: outside

OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

example: debian

fieldDescription:
Operating system name, including the version or code name.

type: keyword

Multi-fields:

* os.full.text (type: match_only_text)

example: Mac OS Mojave

os.description

fieldDescription:
Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

type: keyword

example: 4.4.0-112-generic

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Operating system name, without the version.

type: keyword

* os.name.text (type: match_only_text)

example: Mac OS X

os.name

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

type: keyword

example: darwin

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields describing an entity observing the event from outside the host.'>Observer</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Use the os.type field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.

If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

Expected values for this field:

* linux
* macos
* unix
* windows
* ios
* android

type: keyword

example: macos

os.type

Note: The expected values in ECS for os.type do not correspond with the values defined in semantic conventions!

fieldDescription:
Operating system version as a raw string.

type: keyword

example: 10.14.1

fieldDescription:

The version of the cluster.

Namespace in which the action is taking place.

The list of annotations added to the resource.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Unique ID of the resource being acted upon.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
IP address assigned to the resource associated with the event being observed. In the case of a Kubernetes Pod, this array would contain only one element: the IP of the Pod (as opposed to the Node on which the Pod is running).

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>

Name of the resource being acted upon.

type: keyword

example: test-pod-cdcws

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>

Type or kind of the parent resource associated with the event being observed. In Kubernetes, this will be the name of a built-in workload resource (e.g., Deployment, StatefulSet, DaemonSet).

type: keyword

example: DaemonSet

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Type of resource being acted upon.

type: keyword

example: service

Orchestrator cluster type (e.g. kubernetes, nomad or cloudfoundry).

type: keyword

example: kubernetes

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. A set of static or semi-static attributes of the entity. Usually boolean or keyword field data types. Use this field set when you need to track static or semi-static characteristics of an entity for advanced searching and correlation of normalized values across different providers/sources and entity types.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. A set of ephemeral characteristics of the entity, derived from observed behaviors during a specific time period. Usually boolean field data type. Use this field set when you need to capture and track ephemeral characteristics of an entity for advanced searching, correlation of normalized values across different providers/sources and entity types.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. An optional field used when a pretty name is desired for entity-centric operations. This field should not be used for correlation with *.name fields for entities with dedicated field sets (e.g., host).

type: keyword

Multi-fields:

* entity.display_name.text (type: match_only_text)

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A unique identifier for the entity. When multiple identifiers exist, this should be the most stable and commonly used identifier that: 1) persists across the entity's lifecycle, 2) ensures uniqueness within its scope, 3) is commonly used for queries and correlation, and 4) is readily available in most observations (logs/events). For entities with dedicated field sets (e.g., host, user), this value should match the corresponding *.id field. Alternative identifiers (e.g., ARNs values in AWS, URLs) can be preserved in the raw field.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. Indicates the date/time when this entity was last "seen," usually based upon the last event/log that is initiated by this entity.

type: date

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. A set of temporal characteristics of the entity. Usually date field data type. Use this field set when you need to track temporal characteristics of an entity for advanced searching and correlation of normalized values across different providers/sources and entity types.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. Field set for any fields containing numeric entity metrics. These use dynamic field data type mapping.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. The name of the entity. The keyword field enables exact matches for filtering and aggregations, while the text field enables full-text search. For entities with dedicated field sets (e.g., host), this field should mirrors the corresponding .name value.

type: keyword

Multi-fields:

entity.name.text (type: match_only_text)

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. Original, unmodified fields from the source system. Usually flattened field data type. While the attributes field should be used for normalized fields requiring advanced queries, this field preserves all source metadata with basic search capabilities.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. A URI, URL, or other direct reference to access or locate the entity in its source system. This could be an API endpoint, web console URL, or other addressable location. Format may vary by entity type and source system.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. The module or integration that provided this entity data (similar to event.module).

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. The specific type designation for the entity as defined by its provider or system. This field provides more granular classification than the type field. Examples: aws_s3_bucket, gcp_cloud_storage_bucket, azure_blob_container would all map to entity type bucket. hardware , virtual , container , node , cloud_instance would all map to entity type host.

type: keyword

example: aws_s3_bucket

fieldSet: <abbr title='Fields relevant to container orchestrators.'>Orchestrator</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This field is beta and subject to change. A standardized high-level classification of the entity. This provides a normalized way to group similar entities across different providers or systems. Example values: bucket, database, container, function, queue, host, user, application, session, cloud, orchestrator, etc. If an entity is nested under a top-level namespace like host or cloud, or similar, its type array should include the matching value for example, host or cloud.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

Important: The field value must be one of the following:

bucket, database, container, function, queue, host, user, application, service, session, cloud, orchestrator

To learn more about when to use which value, visit the page allowed values for entity.type

example: 62231

fieldDescription:
Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

type: keyword

example: Paint

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

example: 6.3.9600.17415

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the Go language imports in a PE file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.

The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

type: keyword

example: 10bddcb4cee42080f76c88d9ff964491

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of imported Go language element names and types.

type: flattened

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

type: boolean

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.

Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

type: keyword

example: 0c6803c4e922103c4dca5963aad36ddf

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.

This is a synonym for imphash.

type: keyword

example: d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
List of imported element names and types.

type: flattened

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

type: keyword

example: MSPAINT.EXE

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A hash of the PE header and data from one or more PE sections. An pehash can be used to cluster files by transforming structural information about a file into a hash value.

Learn more at https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/leet09/tech/full_papers/wicherski/wicherski_html/index.html.

type: keyword

example: 73ff189b63cd6be375a7ff25179a38d347651975

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

type: keyword

example: Microsoft Windows Operating System

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
An array containing an object for each section of the PE file.

The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath pe.sections.*.

type: nested

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
PE Section List name.

type: keyword

fieldDescription:
PE Section List physical size.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain Windows Portable Executable (PE) metadata.'>PE Header</abbr>
fieldDescription:
PE Section List virtual size. This is always the same as physical_size.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.

May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["/usr/bin/ssh", "-l", "user", "10.0.0.16"]

process.command_args

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Length of the process.args array.

This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

type: long

example: 4

process.args_count

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.

Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

type: wildcard

Multi-fields:

* process.command_line.text (type: match_only_text)

example: /usr/bin/ssh -l user 10.0.0.16

process.command_line

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The time the process ended.

type: date

example: 2016-05-23T08:05:34.853Z

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Unique identifier for the process.

The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.

Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

type: keyword

example: c2c455d9f99375d

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Array of environment variable bindings. Captured from a snapshot of the environment at the time of execution.

May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin", "USER=ubuntu"]

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Absolute path to the process executable.

type: keyword

Multi-fields:

* process.executable.text (type: match_only_text)

example: /usr/bin/ssh

process.executable.path

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The exit code of the process, if this is a termination event.

The field should be absent if there is no exit code for the event (e.g. process start).

type: long

example: 137

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.

Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.

Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

type: boolean

example: True

process.interactive

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A chunk of input or output (IO) from a single process.

This field only appears on the top level process object, which is the process that wrote the output or read the input.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
An array of byte offsets and lengths denoting where IO data has been skipped.

type: object

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The length of bytes skipped.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The byte offset into this event's io.text (or io.bytes in the future) where length bytes were skipped.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
If true, the process producing the output has exceeded the max_kilobytes_per_process configuration setting.

type: boolean

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
A chunk of output or input sanitized to UTF-8.

Best efforts are made to ensure complete lines are captured in these events. Assumptions should NOT be made that multiple lines will appear in the same event. TTY output may contain terminal control codes such as for cursor movement, so some string queries may not match due to terminal codes inserted between characters of a word.

type: wildcard

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The total number of bytes captured in this event.

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The total number of bytes that were not captured due to implementation restrictions such as buffer size limits. Implementors should strive to ensure this value is always zero

type: long

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The type of object on which the IO action (read or write) was taken.

Currently only 'tty' is supported. Other types may be added in the future for 'file' and 'socket' support.

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Process name.

Sometimes called program name or similar.

type: keyword

Multi-fields:

* process.name.text (type: match_only_text)

example: ssh

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Process id.

type: long

example: 4242

process.pid

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The time the process started.

type: date

example: 2016-05-23T08:05:34.853Z

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This is the set of capabilities used by the kernel to perform permission checks for the thread.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["CAP_BPF", "CAP_SYS_ADMIN"]

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
This is a limiting superset for the effective capabilities that the thread may assume.

type: keyword

Note: This field should contain an array of values.

example: ["CAP_BPF", "CAP_SYS_ADMIN"]

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Thread ID.

type: long

example: 4242

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Thread name.

type: keyword

example: thread-0

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Process title.

The proctitle, some times the same as process name. Can also be different: for example a browser setting its title to the web page currently opened.

type: keyword

Multi-fields:

* process.title.text (type: match_only_text)

process.title

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Information about the controlling TTY device. If set, the process belongs to an interactive session.

type: object

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

type: long

example: 4

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel dont use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

type: long

example: 1

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The number of character columns per line. e.g terminal width

Terminal sizes can change, so this value reflects the maximum value for a given IO event. i.e. where event.action = 'text_output'

type: long

example: 80

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The number of character rows in the terminal. e.g terminal height

Terminal sizes can change, so this value reflects the maximum value for a given IO event. i.e. where event.action = 'text_output'

type: long

example: 24

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Seconds the process has been up.

type: long

example: 1325

process.uptime

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
Virtual process id.

The process id within a pid namespace. This is not necessarily unique across all processes on the host but it is unique within the process namespace that the process exists within.

type: long

example: 4242

process.vpid

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:
The working directory of the process.

type: keyword

* process.working_directory.text (type: match_only_text)

process.working_directory

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
fieldDescription:

type: keyword

fieldSet: <abbr title='These fields contain information about a process.'>Process</abbr>
